awd_titl_txt: Bose-Einstein Condensation Beyond Mean Field: A Partial Differential Equation Approach to Quantum Fluctuations
awd_abstract_narration:
This research addresses a series of challenging questions for the physics of very cold atoms by analytical methods of applied mathematics. In Bose-Einstein condensation, a certain type of particles (bosons) occupy a single macroscopic quantum state called condensate at very low temperatures. This condensate is one of the most coherent states of matter known to date, allowing for a precise control of atomic systems in laboratory settings. The Bose-Einstein condensation has been observed experimentally in atomic gases that are trapped through magnetic and optical means, and has sparked active experimental research into attractive applications of fundamental importance in quantum information and computation, e.g., the design and construction of quantum atomic computers, as well as in precision measurements. The investigator of this project will develop models and carry out analysis that will lead to a better and more fundamental understanding of atomic effects in Bose-Einstein condensation. The impact of this research will be felt by the applied mathematics community as well as by communities of some of the applications, including atomic and condensed-matter physicists, and computer scientists and engineers with specialty in quantum information. The investigator will train one graduate student who will gain interdisciplinary research education and perspective in cutting-edge problems of modern science. 

The goal of this research is to develop a hierarchy of models and analytical tools in order to link the motion and interactions of individual atoms to the macroscopic properties of ultra-cold atomic gases in Bose-Einstein condensation. The methods invoked in this project single out the effect of pair excitations, which cause the many-body wave function of such systems to deviate from the usual mean-field tensor product of one-particle states. The methods of the investigator include: (i) perturbation theory for many-body operators, which links the microscopic Hamiltonian to systems of low-dimensional partial differential equations; (ii) homogenization of the derived systems of equations for settings with microstructures of experimental relevance; and (iii) the global existence and uniqueness of the resulting partial differential equations. This research effort will elucidate fundamental mechanisms of controlling the condensate through the many-body wave function, hence improving past predictions based solely on mean-field theory. Results obtained in this direction can guide simulations of and experiments related to complex condensed-matter systems, and the design of new devices for quantum information and precision metrology.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed a series of quantitative questions that were initially motivated by laboratory experiments involving novel gases of ultra-cold atoms. These systems exhibit interacting  atoms in one of the most coherent macroscopic states known to date: the Bose-Einstein condensate. Because of this strong coherence, the condensate has a behavior that is very similar to that of a well-focused laser beam in optical devices. This situation is usually described by the ``mean field model'' in theoretical physics. This noteworthy attribute of cold atomic systems is technologically appealing and can be controlled via external forces, which act as traps for the interacting particles in the laboratory setting. This capability has been applied, for example, to achieve very accurate measurements in nanotechnology at low temperatures. 

The main outcome of this research was to elucidate by quantitative and systematic means how large-scale effects originating from atomic interactions, particularly the collective excitations of atoms of the condensate in pairs, can potentially distort the expected strong coherence. In order to describe this possibility in a predictive manner, this research effort developed the pair excitation formalism. By this tool, one can predict how the behavior of the condensate can deviate from that of the usual laser beam at sufficiently long times. Consequently, results of this research advance knowledge on the dynamics of collective atomic excitations, beyond the common wisdom acquired previously via the mean field model and its variants. The mathematical methods used in this direction touched upon aspects of physical excitations in other systems, besides those in gases of cold atoms. These excitations include the collective excitations of the electron charge in novel two-dimensional materials, e.g., graphene, which can be used as platforms for the control of light-matter interactions at the nanoscale. 

 The impact of this research lies at the crossroads of applied mathematics, atomic physics and other disciplines such as computer science at the level of quantum information. Results obtained in this direction have the potential to guide the development of large-scale computer algorithms and simulations for complex atomic systems; and provide clues for new questions in future laboratory experiments concerning deviations of systems from the mean field behavior in atomic physics. Hence, these research outcomes can help the design of devices for quantum information and precision metrology. 

 In the context of this project, the principal investigator trained one graduate student of applied mathematics at the University of Maryland. This young person gained a fresh perspective in formulating and tackling modern problems across mathematics and physics. By the dissemination of the research results through the delivery of research seminars, the co-organization of interdisciplinary workshops and conferences, the teaching of courses, and publications in refereed journals, the principal investigator communicated these advances to a wide part of the scientific community including senior and young researchers as well as graduate and undergraduate students of various disciplines.
